scenarios.title: Notice of Entry
scenarios.description: Property staff want to enter a tenant’s unit tomorrow to check a leak, but no formal notice has been given.
scenarios.question: What should occur before entry?

options.A: Immediate entry without notice is allowed
options.B: Provide proper notice unless there is an emergency
options.C: Ask the service provider to approve entry

scenarios.explanation: Landlords generally must give proper notice before entry, absent an emergency.

scenarios.title: Family with Children
scenarios.description: A leasing agent says they won’t rent upper‑floor units to families with children for ‘noise concerns’.
scenarios.question: Is this lawful?

options.B: Yes, if noise complaints are frequent
options.C: No, it likely violates the Fair Housing Act (familial status)
options.D: No, but only in rent‑controlled buildings

scenarios.explanation: Steering or denying based on familial status is discriminatory under fair housing laws.

scenarios.title: No‑Cause Notice after Complaint
scenarios.description: After a tenant reports mold and requests repairs, the landlord issues a no‑cause notice to vacate.
scenarios.question: How should this be viewed?

options.A: Likely lawful if rent is current

scenarios.explanation: Issuing a notice after a tenant asserts rights may constitute unlawful retaliation.

scenarios.title: Accommodation Request
scenarios.description: A tenant with a mobility disability requests a reserved parking space close to the entrance.
scenarios.question: What is the best response?

options.A: Deny because spaces are first‑come, first‑served
options.B: Deny unless the tenant reveals all medical records
options.C: Engage in the interactive process to provide a reasonable accommodation
options.D: Approve only if rent is increased

scenarios.explanation: Reasonable accommodations should be considered to ensure equal access.
